awd_titl_txt: Next-generation, feedback-responsive cell factories for recombinant protein manufacturing
awd_abstract_narration:
Proteins are used to treat a wide variety of diseases. These include several cancers, kidney failure and rheumatoid arthritis, to name a few. Production of therapeutic proteins has increased dramatically over the last decade and is expected to continue to rise for the next decade as treatments are developed for a larger number of diseases. Most of these proteins are produced from mammalian cells, which are the most capable of producing proteins with activity in humans. However, they are also limited in their ability to manufacture protein at large scale. This project will evaluate a number of strategies designed to increase protein production in mammalian cells. Education and training opportunities will target high school teachers and students from the Greater Houston area. This will enhance and diversify the pipeline of a STEM-ready workforce.

Many complex recombinant proteins are manufactured in mammalian cells. The yield depends both on cell productivity and cell growth. Overexpression of recombinant proteins causes the accumulation of misfolded proteins and proteotoxic stress. These, in turn, lead to activation of a global response that may ultimately inhibit protein synthesis and reduce cell viability. This response culminates in the stimulation of protein degradation. The fate of the cell depends on the relative rates of activation of the signaling pathways involved in the response. The project team will use a recently-developed in-house technology to monitor gene expression with high sensitivity and dynamic resolution. Expression of markers of the protein quality control system upon overexpression of representative recombinant proteins will be profiled. Results will be used to generate strategies to remodel the stress response pathway, enhance quality control, and delay cell death in cells expressing high levels of recombinant proteins. Because of the fundamental role of the stress response in maintaining cellular homeostasis, results from this study will impact the design of a variety of cell engineering applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The production of soluble and therapeutic proteins remains one of the main challenges in the field of biotechnology. Therapeutic proteins are the largest class of therapeutic drugs and are used for the treatment of a large range of diseases, ranging from rare and orphan indications to those affecting millions. The increasing demand for therapeutic proteins has resulted in a significant amount of global manufacturing capacity devoted to protein production and substantial effort to improve methods for protein manufacturing.

Therapeutic proteins are typically manufactured in mammalian cells: the yield of production depends both on cell productivity and cell growth as protein overexpression causes accumulation of misfolded proteins and proteotoxic stress, which leads to activation of a global response aimed at restoring homeostasis that may ultimately inhibit protein synthesis and reduce cell viability. Accumulation of misfolded proteins triggers the activation of a cellular stress response. sustained cellular stress, however, results in the activation of cellular death by apoptosis. This highly dynamic system requires sophisticated tools for both detection and manipulation. To address the limitations of currently available tools, we developed a synthetic biology platform technology for monitoring and manipulating cellular stress pathways with high sensitivity. This platform enabled the engineering of next-generation cell factories that enhance pathways for stress attenuation and delay apoptosis to enhance protein manufacturing.

 

Intellectual Merit:

Results from this study generated the design rules to manipulate the UPR to control cellular fate. Designed to sense fluctuations in cellular stress at the single-cell level, this approach is poised to resolve the natural heterogeneity of cell populations with respect to UPR activation. 

 

Broader Impacts:

This research program provided broadly reaching educational and training opportunities to students belonging to underrepresented groups with the overall goal of increasing diversity in STEM. Specifically, this research program was leveraged to 1) provide training, research, and mentoring opportunities for high school teachers and students from the Greater Houston area, 2) improve teaching and learning for college students, and 3) build the university infrastructure that supports the career development of faculty and postdoctoral fellows.
